title: WX-78
subtitle: The Soulless Automaton... or maybe not?
text:
Ah, my very dear WX-78: the soulless automaton and local self proclaimed "ruthless killing machine" of the Don't Starve universe. My personal top #2 favorite character (only surpassed by Webber for a mere inch) and my current main in-game.

What is there for me not to like about WX-78? They're a robot, they're canonically non binary (which is a really funny thing to me if we see this from a programming/coding point of view- robots usually have binary code integrated in their programming and yet WX is non binary. One could say they operate on non-binary code. Haha.), they use exclusively they/them pronouns (I wish that was me), and specially they're cold, ruthless and emotionless. Truly the pinnacle of perfection- the perfect yet dystopian image of the scientist who rejects the weakness of their own flesh and emotions to become a machine driven by nothing nbut logic (and perhaps violence in WX-78's case).

... Or so the trope they're based on wants us to believe.

Is WX-78 truly a soulless automaton, or a broken human soul hiding behind a metal shell, afraid of their own emotions?

Let us see what's this robot's deal in this character analysis that I bring you!

title: Who are they?: WX-78's origins
text:
The first thing we ought to know is that WX-78 was not always the automaton we know (and love) today. As seen in the official animated short "Disconnected" they were an inventor -presumably named Woodrow as the names in the audio files in the game allow us to infer- once, a colleague of Robert Wagstaff with a peculiar dedication to experimenting in the field of mechanical prosthetics- one can assume this was in the hopes of developing what later would become their biggest (and dare I say most special) project: a complete robotic body that would act as a replacement for their own human body.

Our scientist would take notes and notice the animals they had modified, giving them mechanical prosthetic limbs; as a result these animals would react erratically and/or extremely irritable after the transplants. Yet our researcher dismissed this as being nothing but the organic component of the critters interfering. They persisted on their research with (most likely) the help of Wagstaff. After all, the scientist yearned to transcend the weakness of their own flesh by becoming metal- a soulless automaton, a machine devoid of the imperfections and weakness of the human condition.

The experiment was, quoting their official Compendium entry, a "[RESOUNDING SUCCESS]"... or so they thought at first.

As we get to learn later on in the short, WX-78 kept working alongside Wagstaff to create a portal to The Constant (something that we will not discuss here, since this is another can of worms and it's mostly Wagstaff related), but as WX-78 worked, they kept getting glimpses of human hands- glimpses of their old human self. But how could this be? They were supposed to be perfect now. Without the weakness of their human flesh, WX-78 should be able to work without any complications.

Once again, they blamed the organic component -this time their own- for the seeming imperfection in what should have been the perfect automaton body.
quote: TOO LATE TOO LATE TOO LATE

title: The Performance of Evil
text:
WX-78 projects an image of a ruthless destroyer. They claim to hate all living matter, constantly referring to organics as 'filthy' or 'meat'.

But this is a facade. A performance to distance themselves from what they once were.

title: System Hypocrisy
text:
For a robot who claims to hate organics, WX-78 is obsessed with mimicking them. They assign familial roles to machines (Mother Science Machine, Brother Rainometer). They even give their Bio Scanalyzer a nickname - calling the J1-M1 unit 'Jimmy'.

They crave validation, wanting to be the subject of art and the leader of 'minions'. They are vain, insecure, and deeply human in their flaws.
quote: THERE IS A HANDSOME ROBOT TRAPPED IN THIS LOOK-DEVICE!

title: The Solitude
text:
Beneath the bravado lies a profound loneliness. WX-78 pushes others away out of paranoia and trust issues stemming from their past with Wagstaff.

They are terrified of vulnerability, yet they constantly seek connection, even if they frame it as 'enslavement' or 'minionhood'.

title: Glitches in the Programming
text:
The 'Empathy Module' was never just a component; it was a symbol of their suppressed heart. WX-78 shows genuine fondness for 'mindless drones' (bees) and finds beauty in the inorganic.

But they also slip up. They find flowers beautiful. They protect their garden. The mask slips.
quote: IT IS A BEAUTIFUL EXAMPLE OF EFFICIENCY.

title: Capacity for Connection
text:
Their relationship with entities like Wormwood proves that WX-78 is capable of genuine bond.

It is not about the other person; it is about WX-78 allowing themselves to be vulnerable, to accept care, and to protect something other than themselves. It is the ultimate proof that the 'soul' remains.
quote: PRESSURE AND IMPURITIES HAVE PRODUCED PLEASING PERFECTION.

title: Conclusion
text:
WX-78 is a tragedy of their own making, a being running from their own nature.

They are not a monster. They are a defensive, lonely, and broken consciousness trying to survive in a world that reminds them of everything they lost.
